final_answer.precision_note: Reported to 3 significant figures, consistent with the current (1.50 A, 3 s.f.) and time (30.0 min, 3 s.f.) data.

method: Step 1: Calculate total charge passed using Q = I × t from L17. Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min × 60 = 1800 s. Q = 1.50 A × 1800 s = 2700 C (using I = 1.50 A from L51, t = 30.0 min from L51). Step 2: Calculate moles of electrons using n(e-) = Q / F from L18 with F = 96,500 C mol-1 from L19. n(e-) = 2700 / 96500 = 0.02798 mol. Step 3: Use half-equation from L52 (Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu) which shows 2 moles of electrons deposit 1 mole of Cu. Therefore n(Cu) = n(e-) / 2 = 0.02798 / 2 = 0.01399 mol. Step 4: Calculate mass of copper using m = n × Ar with Ar(Cu) = 63.55 from L24. Mass Cu = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.888 g to 3 s.f.
checks: Unit check: A × s = C, C / (C mol-1) = mol, mol × g mol-1 = g, all units consistent.
Stoichiometry check: 2 electrons per Cu2+ ion reduced, so moles Cu = moles e- / 2.
